posts.cooked:
I know Signal-iOS/CONTRIBUTING.md says we shouldn’t add more options but I believe Signal is a general-purpose messaging app and doesn’t try to address a specific threat model. Are you chatting with a trusted friend? Are you chatting with someone else? Is the adversary the network? Is the adversary the person you are chatting with? (Assuming you don’t know them very well or trust them fully)

Right now Signal strips meta-data from photos before sending them to the other person. But there are cases where it is desirable to share the meta-data because revealing EXIF location and other info is not part of the threat model. E.g., between friends where the network is the only adversary.

In fact the missing meta-data might ruin the experience and turn users away from Signal.

This is a request to add a UI element giving the option to keep or strip the meta-data in photos, per conversation or globally. It should default to removing the meta-data.

P.S.: I’m open to suggestions how the meta-data sanitization policy can be determined without adding an option.

posts.cooked:
This is the first time I hear that someone actually uses that data (as compared to having it used against him).

BTW, if you send the image as a file, does it still strip the metadata? I think not but I can’t test right now.

From my brief test, the EXIF data was still removed. And btw, the filename extension is changed from “.jpg” to “.jpeg”.

While I understand Signal is a “privacy” app, I’m a little put out by an app intercepting my binary files (pics etc), and modifying it without my permission. How far do we take this? Should we also blur text and faces in photos and video?

For me, I’m using Signal with people I know / trust. I just don’t want eavesdropping or interference.

I agree with @kontaxis about the current image metadata situation. Most times sending metadata removed images is best but there are time when I want to send an original image to a contact and Signal is the quickest most secure way to get it to them.

Below I made two mockups of how to implement metadata removing as a TOOL, rather than a mandatory function.

Mockup One has the metadata remover tool icon placed inside the image edit page when sending an image.

Signal Image Metadata Remover Tool_001.png4000×2000 199 KB

Notes:

  • The RED boxes are the icons
  • Depending on how this would be implemented (auto on/off) the icon could change to show if an image has metadata to remove, image already removed metadata and/or to remove image metadata.
  • After tapping the icon a dialogue box would open to confirm that metadata will be removed.

Mockup Two has the metadata remover tool icon right away by the edit image icon when sending an image. This position would allow faster access to metadata remover tool than mockup one.

Signal Image Metadata Remover Tool_002.png4000×2000 293 KB

Notes:

  • The BLUE boxes are the icons
  • Depending on how this would be implemented (auto on/off) the icon could change to show if an image has metadata to remove, image already removed metadata and/or to remove image metadata.
  • After tapping the icon a dialogue box would open to confirm that metadata will be removed.

I think sending as “File” should be fixed so that no EXIF data is removed. This would save us from having an extra option and hopefully be kind of intuitive. Image: send the picture, so we can look at the same thing. File: send the whole file as is.

Right now the options I have when clicking on the paperclip icon are: Camera, Photo Library, GIF, Document.

All of these could have meta-data that the user may or may not want removed.

And how is a “file” different from a photo?
Technically everything is a file and creating an arbitrary distinction between “files” and other things would be very confusing.
I would argue that when meta-data is removed we are not looking at the same thing, for example, because the receiver’s phone renders a nice map below the photo using the location meta-data and in this case it won’t but the sender’s will.

I don’t think this is about specific files, I think this is about trust in the person you are chatting with.
Exchanging photos is the most obvious case that demonstrates the issue.

Either the person on the other end is part of the threat model in which case you want to reveal as little information as possible about you (remove all meta-data from everything you send, etc.) or the person is not part of the threat model (i.e., trusted contact) in which case you shouldn’t remove any meta-data or take any other defensive action against them and instead focus on the network which I believe is always part of the threat model and is the original threat model of Signal.

So ultimately the question we need to ask* users is: do you trust this person?

  • No. (Default) Strip meta-data from all files sent over and possibly take other defensive actions. (E.g., “Hey you appear to be typing a phone number / address etc / credit card number.”)
  • Yes. Don’t strip meta-data from the files sent and don’t try to protect the sender from the receiver.

*: I’m not actually proposing we prompt users but instead have a switch that can mark a conversation as trusted. If users don’t know where the switch is then great, the conversation remains untrusted and the system fails closed.

posts.cooked: Same. It feels controlling and intrusive on the part of Signal to mess with my data in this way. As a network, Signal is violating network neutrality. If Signal wants to be paternalistic, then let it strip the metadata by default, but for those of us who know just what our threat models are and are not, we should have an option. It is highly inconvenient to not be able to strip original photographs with metadata with one of my friends.

If this ends up not being a desired feature, at the very least, could Signal write a time and date stamp back to a file when it is saved? The non-existence of time and date stamp when an image file is saved messes up the photo order in the device’s gallery app. In previous versions of Signal, the photos were stamped as the time and date saved, not when they were taken, so this wouldn’t necessarily affect the privacy of the sender. Can this be put back in? Should this be a bug? The current behavior seems to be that there is no date/time stamp at all when an image is saved.

Now in 2021 where a significant portion of my social graph moved to Signal, it became a realistic channel for photo-sharing with friends.

But stripping the photo metadata significantly destroys the digitally assisted (=semi automatic) photo/video user experience such as chronological sorting and/or geo-locating/filtering. A UX which is necessary for the amount of media which we create/share/consume in our daily lives nowadays. If it’s too cumbersome and chaotic, nobody will use it, not even tech-savvy people.

I read through this whole threat, my points:

  • In the sense of an E2EE messenger the default should be the safest choice “no metadata at all”
    (not even the original filename)
  • But responsible/aware users should have the opportunity to turn metadata-stripping off:
    Globally, per user, per occasion.
  • @mikaseh thanks for having started with the UX design for the “per occasion” use cases.
    • But ofc, there’s still user research, and still UX design to be done.
    • For plently use cases, i.e. sending in batch inside Signal, or when receiving pic(s) via Share button from other apps, etc
    • And to get even more complex, fine grained control over what to strip:
      Date/time, location, all other EXIF, especially very identifying attributes such as camera maker/model, and UIDs such as camera serial number.
    • Apple has that usability already figured out, see iMessage and Photos in that regard.
  • @maintainers: Please give this topic attention!
    • Before investing energy into new features like Payments via Signal better
    • First get core features of a messenger like photo/video sharing to an acceptable UX level!
    • Please state here whether you consider this issue important for tackling it — and then the community and/or your internal user experience researchers/designers and developers could kick off the discussion on the plenty design details: WHERE to strip WHAT metadata-attributes and HOW that is accessible to the user.
    • But please let us know! This topic is popularly relevant as duplicate/related issues show:
      • Ability to send media files unaltered (EXIF/metadata, resizing)
      • Give user the option to send/receive full-quality images
      • List of meta data which should be displayed when sending certain file-formats

posts.cooked:
I would like to add my vote to this request. EXIF data can be dangerous in some circumstances and having a security-first default makes sense, but it is also a feature many people, me included, would like the ability to use.
Ideally there would be “Remove EXIF data” switches on multiple levels:

  • Global setting (default: on)
  • Per conversation setting (default: global)
  • Per image(s) sent in one message (default: conversation)

The most important one of these for me would be the second one because it aligns with the trust/threat level associated with a specific conversation. The other two would be convenience.

We should keep this simple and easy to implement for now but more detailed settings like »keep time« and »keep location« would also be nice.

I appreciate the Signal default of removing all metadata before sending media files (most notably EXIF data from image files). The service’s focus is on privacy and security, so this is completely sensible.

However, Signal is also used as a messenger between people who trust each other (at least to a certain degree), where the aim of privacy and security is more to protect the conversation from other parties than to protect the sender from the recipient (or vice versa).

Media metadata can constitute valuable information that one might explicitly want the recipient to receive. Not all images sent through Signal (or any similar messenger) are just momentary snapshots for which metadata are of no particular use. An image’s creation date, for example, enables the recipient to integrate the image into a photo library and have it sorted correctly there. Similarly for location. A colorspace tag enables viewing images properly when viewed on color-managed systems (which are now quite common). Technical infos in EXIF are sometimes illuminating, too. Even the original filename is often helpful to retain (when devices with an exposed filesystem are involved, most notably in the case of Signal Desktop). And for videos, having the original file creation date instead of the date the video was sent can be very helpful as well, as the former often corresponds with the date the video was actually taken.

Or, in other words, for the very same reasons that, as a default, it is prudent for Signal to remove all metadata from files, it would be sensible to retain them when the user deems the conversation – or the occasion – safe. After all, being able to freely exchange sensitive information is exactly the point of having a secure, private connection to another user! But currently, it is simply impossible to share media files with metadata intact (save for sending them inside a zip file, I guess, but that is completely impractical for daily use).

So, a user preference to preserve metadata for media files would be greatly appreciated. Since it is probably too risky to implement this as a global option, my proposal would be to offer it as an option for each conversation individually. Or, at the very least, provide some method in the conversation view to easily send individual media files without having their metadata stripped, though that would also not be very practical for daily use.

(For complete ability to send media files exactly how they are, there would also have to be a way to prevent Signal from resizing and recompressing images – but that is probably another topic.)

posts.cooked:
I absolutely agree there should be a method of attaching files that does not modify the files in any way (including file name, file creation date, keywords, EXIF data and anything else), and that that would take care of both the media file metadata problem as well as the recompress/resize problem.

However, I see issues with that approach:

  1. If the existing “attach as file” method were used for this (as a default behavior), there would be no way anymore of attaching a non-media files with protection from unintended metadata transmission. Not good.

  2. If this were implemented as an additional method of attaching files, it would imply UI problems (e.g. how to differentiate “attach as file” from “attach as file without modifications” so users won’t inadvertently confuse them?), and more importantly, it wouldn’t be a good solution for everyday use. On iOS, you’d have to tap “+”, “File (unmodified)” (or whatever it would be called) and then “Photo Library” or “Browse” before you even got to selecting the image(s), as opposed to just tapping the image(s) in the preview strip (two taps less) or tapping the Photo Library icon therein (one tap less) or sharing directly from another app (not clear how to access an “attach as unmodified file” option at all). In any case, not practical to do multiple times a day, I think.

  3. On Signal Desktop (which I primarily use) there is no differentiation between “attaching an image” and “attaching a file”. There is only a “+” for attaching something, or drag and drop. So it wouldn’t be clear how to bring this functionality to Signal Desktop without considerable design changes there. Personally, having this implemented only on mobile devices wouldn’t help me much at all.

My proposal is to keep it simple for both the developers and the users. If there is simply an additional switch (or several) in the conversation settings, nothing changes about the primary conversation UI itself, the default behavior stays the same, and when the option is switched on, Signal could just skip the metadata stripping (and possibly resizing and recompressing) step internally before sending media files. The user would enjoy the desired handling of media files while continuing to use the standard sharing UI elements. And this could be added easily for Signal Desktop, too, as an additional option (or options) in the “…” menu inside the conversation view.

Again, I’d very much like to see a plain “attach and don’t modify” option as well, but I fear it is unrealistic at this point to expect it to be implemented, and would be cumbersome to use for routine image sharing even if implemented. In any case, it would be a different feature request than the present one.

@DirkPitt1 and @sampumon

I don’t think polling the user every time he tries to send an image would be wise – constant nuisance that many (most?) users don’t care about. But I agree having all three options available would be ideal. I’d just tuck them away in the conversation settings so they’d be switchable per conversation and wouldn’t get in the way of someone using Signal “as is”.

For simplicity’s sake, one could probably do with only one option “Don’t downsize” though, instead of separate options for resizing and recompressing. Resizing implies recompressing, and I don’t think allowing recompressing but prohibiting resizing makes much sense – you’d only want recompressing in order to save bandwidth or storage, and then you’d be likely to want to have images downsized as well.

Not sure if one would have to differentiate between images and movies for those options… One might conceivably want to send images unaltered but have movies downsized, since they are much larger…

PS: If a moderator is reading this, maybe the topic’s title could be changed to include the resize/recompress issue as well: “Ability to send media files unaltered (EXIF/metadata, resizing)” might be more accurate.

awaitlink:

Another thing to think about in this “conversation-wide setting” case is what happens when forwarding media to a different conversation (which isn’t possible in Signal Desktop at the moment, but is on mobile).

Good point, I hadn’t thought of the case of forwarding.

I don’t believe the forwarder’s setting for the source conversation is relevant here, since that setting naturally pertains only to sending files within that conversation, not to receiving them or to sending them elsewhere. Or did you mean the sender’s setting for the source conversation in your top row? In that case, I’d say we can’t know that, or at least not directly. We can only know if a received file has metadata or not.

I think there is really only one problematic case here: when I receive a file with metadata (implying the sender had that conversation set to “Keep”) and proceed to forward it to another conversation that I have set to “Keep” as well. In all other cases, metadata must either be removed or there is no metadata there to begin with, and thus no danger of inadvertently transmitting it.

For that problematic case (which might be the one you marked with ), I see two options:

  1. Remove all metadata irrespective of the forwarder’s setting for the target conversation.

  2. Honor the forwarder’s setting for the target conversation and keep metadata if that is what is configured (and if metadata is actually present).

Option 2 can lead to the following odd case:

  • A has his conversation with B set to “Keep”.
  • A has his conversation with C set to “Remove”.
  • B has his conversation with C set to “Keep”.
  • B receives a file from A and forwards it to C, with metadata still present.

But I’d argue this is not really problematic. Once you send unaltered files to anyone, there is a possibility of them falling into the wrong hands. Only way to prevent it is to never set conversations to “Keep metadata” (basically that would just be how it is now, and would remain the default).

Even option 1 cannot really prevent the odd case since the forwarder can always simply circumvent the forwarding function by saving the file and attaching it anew, or forwarding the file outside of Signal entirely.

So, I think option 2 is just fine, and also in line with what you should expect from enabling a “Keep metadata” option. I’d actually consider it a feature, since otherwise the same problem I described in the initial post about metadata being removed against the sender’s will would occur again when forwarding media files.
